head.title: Floridians Take Grand National Team Title

hedline.hl1: Floridians Take Grand National Team Title

abstract.p: Alan Truscott bridge column on Florida's defeat of California to capture Grand National Team title at American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals; diagram (M)

block.p: In a battle of world champions, Florida defeated California to capture the Grand National Team title at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here on Saturday night. The Floridians were Jeff Meckstroth, Eric Rodwell and Robert Levin, whose many honors include the World Bridge Federation's Bermuda Bowl, as well as Michael Seamon and Joseph Shay.

They repeated their success last year in San Antonio, winning the final by 68 against the Californians, Chip Martel, Lew Stansby and Peter Weichsel, who have also won the Bermuda Bowl, plus Ron Smith, Kyle Larsen and Rose Johnson Meltzer. The event began nine months ago at grass-roots level.

In a battle of world champions, Florida defeated California to capture the Grand National Team title at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here on Saturday night. The Floridians were Jeff Meckstroth, Eric Rodwell and Robert Levin, whose many honors include the World Bridge Federation's Bermuda Bowl, as well as Michael Seamon and Joseph Shay.

They repeated their success last year in San Antonio, winning the final by 68 against the Californians, Chip Martel, Lew Stansby and Peter Weichsel, who have also won the Bermuda Bowl, plus Ron Smith, Kyle Larsen and Rose Johnson Meltzer. The event began nine months ago at grass-roots level.

The diagramed deal, the last of the 64-deal match, demonstrates the concentration and effort that top players can summon at the end of a tiring day. Levin and Seamon were East and West, defending four hearts after East had opened the bidding with one club.

A routine opening lead of a club would have allowed the contract to succeed, but West diagnosed the possibility of spade ruffs in the dummy and gave the defense a chance by leading a trump. South won in his hand and played three diamond winners, discarding a club from his hand. He then led the singleton spade, and Levin resisted the temptation to put up a winner. Seeing the importance of allowing his partner to win, he played low and was happy when West produced the queen. A second trump lead duly hit the table, and South won in this position:
Diagram

South did the best he could by leading the spade 10 and discarding a club from the dummy. Levin won with the king and administered the coup de grace by underleading his top clubs. Seamon won with the queen and led his last trump.

South had no way to avoid the loss of a fourth trick for down one and a loss of 10 imps. The game succeeded easily in the replay, where North was the declarer in four hearts, and East led the spade king. Levin and Seamon now have a candidate for the International Bridge Press Association's Defense of the Year Award.
